Award.AwardTitle: III: Medium: Private Identification of Relatives and Private GWAS: First Steps in the New Field of CryptoGenomics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The field of human genetics has undergone a revolution in the past 10 years with the advent of high-throughput genomic technologies which can measure human variation at low cost. The flagship application of these technologies has been the genome-wide association study (GWAS) where genetic variation information is collected from hundreds of thousands of individuals, a portion of which have a specific disease and a portion of which are healthy individuals. Identification of correlation between genetic variants with disease status has led to the identification of hundreds of new genes involved in dozens of human diseases. All applications of these technologies, including GWAS, require individuals to "share" their genetic data. In today's typical GWAS, thousands of individuals must consent to have their genetic information collected and incorporated into a database which also contains information on their disease status. Unfortunately, an individual's genetic data is extremely sensitive as it is considered medical information about an individual. In this proposal, the team addresses the natural tension between privacy and the application of personal genomics technologies by capitalizing on recent breakthroughs in cryptography. They present a novel technological approach to keep one's genetic data private, yet taking full advantage of genetic information - in a privacy-preserving way, by taking advantage of several techniques that have been recently developed in an area broadly referred to as secure computing, which address the problem of allowing a collection of individuals to compute some output that depends on all their inputs, without having to reveal their individual inputs to each other. The core of this proposal focuses on the application of secure computing to two specific problems in personal genomics: The first is the problem of identification of relatives from genetic variation information while preserving privacy of genetic material. The second, is the identification of disease causing variants without sacrificing individual patient's genetic privacy.

The development of the techniques presented in this proposal will have a profound impact on personal genomics and the field of genetics in general for several reasons. First, the easing of privacy fears will drop a major barrier to participation in personal genomics likely increasing the utilization of recent advances in genetic and genomic technologies for the public. This increased utilization will accelerate the medical benefits of these technologies. Second, the current thinking is that it is impossible to protect privacy in personal genomics and the results of this project will surprise many in the field, leading to a rethinking of the how to handle privacy in genetic studies. Finally, this research direction will likely lead to new problems and research directions for the cryptography research community and foster new collaborations between genetics researchers, cryptographers and mathematicians.

This project also contributes to training the next generation of interdisciplinary scientists. The investigators all teach advanced undergraduate courses in both genetics and cryptography and it is likely that the topics developed in this proposal will be included in the curriculum of the courses. In addition, the graduate students involved in this proposal will obtain interdisciplinary training in both genetics and computer science theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Application of genomic technologies to an individual’s genome—a field known as personal genomics—has recently gained a lot of interest. Studies in personal genomics often collect genetic information from a set of individuals, then analyze each pair to identify close genetic relatives. Maintaining the privacy of an individual in these studies is a fundamental problem that affects many areas of life science and biomedical science.

This project developed and tested new approaches for preserving the privacy of an individual while performing personal genomics research and genome-wide association studies (GWAS). One challenge to developing novel methods for preserving privacy in genomic studies is the need for interdisciplinary collaboration among the fields of cryptography, genomics, and computer science. We also developed new interdisciplinary collaborations on several levels, and we provided interdisciplinary training to undergraduate students, graduate students, and post-doctoral scholars.

During the first year, we completed a prototype and proof of concept system for private relative identification which is the first portion of the proposed work in the grant proposal. The system allows an individual to compare their own DNA sequences with other individuals to identify which other individuals are related without revealing any information about their DNA sequences to others.

During the second year, we began developing cryptography and genomics methods for identifying relatives. Insights gained during this research form the basis of our methods for determining the genetic relationships between individuals privately. We developed an application that preserves privacy while identifying relatives of an individual. We also developed novel methods for secure computation—allowing researchers to share enough genomic data for the application without compromising privacy. We presented a novel method, IPED, that is capable of reconstructing large pedigrees with reasonable accuracy. IPED was the first practical method for reconstruction of large pedigrees from genotype data. We also published several papers that present critical tools for secure computation; namely, we discuss zero-knowledge proofs that allow participants to prove that they are behaving correctly without revealing any secret information (such as their genetic material).

During the following years, we focused on publishing our methods for identifying relatives while preserving privacy and exploring the other objectives of the proposal—allowing for analysis of genomic data while preserving privacy. We developed a new method for incorporating rare variants in genomic studies, and released software for implementing our published methods. We initiated the theoretical study of randomized processing through an object we call Functional Encryption for Randomized Functionalities, and demonstrated its suitability for private data analysis for genomic data and beyond. We also showed the first feasibility results for such processing. We continued applying insights from cryptography to allow accurate and efficient GWAS results while protecting individual privacy. In addition, we developed and demonstrated the utility of several new tools that will enable an unprecedented level of encryption in terms of genomic data.

This project has broad impact due to its utility in a wide range of scientific problems, the interdisciplinary research opportunities provided to undergraduate and graduate students, and the distribution of software and data. Our project made major contributions to the area of personal genomics. The sequencing revolution will likely cause several million individuals to have their genomes sequenced within the next few years. Our project is building a technological solution to the inherent tradeoff of privacy and benefits in the realm of personal genomics; we made substantial progress on methods that will allow people to participate in genomic studies without revealing their genetic information. We will continue developed and publishing methods related to genomic privacy in the future.

This project also supported an undergraduate research training project. We mentored several students involved in the 2016 and 2017 UCLA Bruins-In-Genomics (B.I.G.) Summer programs. B.I.G. Summer is an intensive, practical experience in genomics and bioinformatics for students who are interested in integrating quantitative and biological knowledge, and pursuing graduate degrees in the biological, biomedical or health sciences. The program includes next generation sequencing analysis workshops, weekly science talks by researchers, a weekly student journal club, professional development seminars, social activities, concluding poster sessions, and GRE test prep courses. In particular, this project’s activities provided educational resources to women and underrepresented minorities involved in B.I.G. Summer. Students developed hands-on experience implementing and testing the novel methods developed by this project, and participants gained authorship on poster presentations as well as upcoming publications in peer-reviewed journals.
